channel.title: posts on Tyler Hext
channel.description: Recent content in posts on Tyler Hext

item.title: Punica Granatum 3
item.description:
Pomegranate (Punica granatum) cutting started in March 2024.

2024 July

Earliest photo of this tree.

2025 January

Did some pretty severe carving on this tree. Hope I didn’t kill it!

I’m trying for a broom style as much as is possible with three branches…at least I’m planning a very symmetrical tree, straight trunk with lots of ramification. The planting angle here is temporary.

item.title: Punica Granatum 4
item.description:
Pomegranate (Punica granatum) cutting started in March 2024.

2024 July

Earliest photo of this tree.

2024 December

Not much. Missing chunk of bark is cool.

2025 January

Repotting day! Happy with the root growth, time to size it up.

Did my best to trim the roots into a single plane here. Time will tell if I overdid it.

item.title: Biscuits
item.description:
Ingredients

  • Flour (2 cups)
  • Granulated sugar (1 tbsp)
  • Baking powder (1 tbsp)
  • Salt (1 tsp)
  • Butter (unsalted, cold) (6 tbsp)
  • Whole milk (3/4 cup)

Instructions

  1. Preheat over to 425 F
  2. Add dry ingredients to a bowl and mix
    • Flour (2 cups)
    • Baking powder (1 tbsp)
    • Sugar (1 tbsp)
    • Salt (1 tsp)
  3. Cube butter and mix into the bowl
    • Butter (6 tbsp)
  4. Add milk, mix
    • Milk (3/4 cup)
  5. Roll out on a floured surface, fold, repeat a couple times
  6. Cut out 6-8 biscuits, place on greased baking sheet
  7. Cook until done (~12 minutes)

Notes

  • Don’t overwork the dough
  • Chunks of butter is okay
  • I use a coffee mug to press out circles from the dough

item.title: Feijoa Sellowiana Seedlings
item.description:
Feijoa sellowiana seedlings started from collected fruit in the fall of 2024.

2024 December

A few of the seedlings I’m trying to start. These were harvested from the fruit of a mature tree in my backyard. I have failed at cuttings and air layers from the same tree in the past. I don’t see many bonsai of this species, I think the bark would make for a cool tree.

For now we wait.

item.title: Pomegranate Propagation
item.description:
pomegranate propagation

I’ve had success propagating pomegranate trees by both cuttings and air layers. Below is the general process I follow for each.

air layer

The biology behind air layers is worth a read but I’ll just cover the basic steps here.

initial prep

In mid-summer get a sharp razorblade and make cuts like this picture. If you timed it well the bark should peel off very easily in step b. The end result should be a ring around the entire branch where bark is removed and inner layer is exposed.

item.title: Portulacaria Afra 1
item.description:
Portulacaria afra cutting started in the summer of 2024.

2024 December

Lots of new growth considering the colder weather recently. Probably will leave this one alone to grow out for the 2025 season.

item.title: Portulacaria Afra 2
item.description:
Portulacaria afra cutting started in the summer of 2024.

2024 December

Not a ton of growth but it still looks healthy. I like the trunk on this one and think there is opportunity for a nice tree here. I’ll likely let this one grow untouched for 2025.

item.title: Punica Granatum 2
item.description:
Pomegranate (Punica granatum) cutting started in March 2024.

2024 July

Initial growth on this cutting. This was ~3 months after a group of cuttings were taken.

2024 December

Depending how the roots look I am planning to chop back to that main curvy branch and use it as the new leader. I’m currently undecided whether I’ll keep any of the other branches.

item.title: Punica Granatum 6
item.description:
Pomegranate (Punica granatum) cutting started in March 2024.

2024 July

Initial growth on this cutting. This was ~3 months after a group of cuttings were taken.

2024 December

Trimmed back after it got attacked by bugs. This tree is root bound and seems happy. It experienced the least dieback of all the thick cuttings. In early spring I will re-scar the chop and try to set up better flow into the new leader.

item.title: Punica Granatum Layer 1
item.description:
Pomegranate air layer started in May 2024.

2024 September

Removal day, approximately 4 months after starting the layer.

2024 December

After a warm fall this tree just decided to keep on growing.

I want to get the sphagnum moss out of the rootball in spring to lessen the risk of root rot. Hopefully I’ll get it into a 3 gallon grow bag at the same time.

item.title: Punica Granatum Neji-Kan 1
item.description:
Neji-kan pomegranate purchased from House of Bonsai in November 2024.

2024 December

Picked this up because I like the trunk. The twisted trunk appearance is one of my favorite styles, looking forward to watching it develop.

I plan to size up the pot with better-draining soil in the spring.

item.title: Ulmus Parvifolia 1
item.description:
Chinese elm (Ulmus parvifolia) purchased from an online bonsai outlet store in spring 2024.

2024 May

Earliest photo I have of this tree. It kept most of its foliage from the journey across the country.

2024 June

Strong summer growth. In hindsight I may have been overwatering at this point.

2024 September

In the fall this tree was not doing well, at one point getting black spots and dropping all of its leaves. It bounced back with some growth shortly after this photo. Looking forward to getting it into better soil soon.

item.title: Bike Light Battery
item.description:
This was a quick hack to convert my bicycle tail light from using AAA batteries to a rechargeable lithium cell. The spare battery came from a disposable vaporizer found on the sidewalk.

This is the inside of the bike light I used. The whole thing is a waterproof shell that comes apart so you can replace batteries in the back, and I wanted to preserve the waterproof seal.

item.title: Punica Granatum 1
item.description:
Pomegranate (Punica granatum) cutting started in March 2024.

2024 July

Initial growth on this cutting. This was ~3 months after a group of cuttings were taken.

2024 December

Trimmed a couple branches. This diameter seems like the sweet spot for hardwood cuttings. I’m considering chopping just above the lowest branch and using the top half as another tree.

item.title: Handwired Keyboard 1
item.description:
handwired keyboard 1

intro

This project started as a way to practice soldering. I also learned a lot about keyboards, the interesting bits highlighted below.

custom firmware

The biggest benefit of building this for me has been the custom firmware. Taking the time to customize a keymap and configure dynamic macros can be a huge efficiency improvement if you do lots of computer things. For example I store phrases that I type frequently behind key combinations, so I can press a couple keys to instantly type my email / password / zoom link. Or I’ll record a macro to reformat multiple lines in a csv file all at once.
